newsitem.title: FRANCE: French, German left discuss EMU terms - spokesman.
newsitem.headline: French, German left discuss EMU terms - spokesman.

text.p: France's Socialist party said on Monday it was holding talks with Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party (SPD) on conditions for a single European currency but they had reached no firm agreement yet.
Socialist party spokesman Francois Hollande told reporters: "There is no text. We have discussions and a serious dialogue. They have come some way towards our positions."

The weekly newsletter La Lettre de l'Expansion said on Monday that French Socialist leader Lionel Jospin and SPD chairman Oskar Lafontaine were discussing changing the Maastricht Treaty to ease the deficit limit of three percent of gross domestic product to 3.5 percent or even 3.7 percent.
The question of conditions for European economic and monetary union is a central issue in the campaign for France's May 25-June 1 parliamentary election.
The centre-right government has said it will freeze public spending in nominal terms this year and next and take further savings measures if necessary to meet the three percent target.
Jospin has ruled out a new bout of austerity if it is necessary to achieve a strict three percent deficit limit and said the criteria should be interpreted as trends.
Hollande told a routine briefing: "The German and French Socialists have never made the criteria into accounting norms. What matters is convergence."

He said the SPD had initially appeared to favour postponing the start of EMU, due on January 1, 1999, but was coming round to the French Socialists' view that it should go ahead on certain conditions.
Hollande the discussions had a somewhat "unreal" feeling, since neither party was in government.
